summary: This document set contains FBI 302 interview reports and related forms from the investigation into the death of Jeffrey Epstein. It includes interviews with inmates (Leonardo Fernandez, Efrain Reyes), Bureau of Prisons staff (lieutenants, corrections officers, psychologist), and documentation of evidence collection and property return. The interviews focus on Epstein's housing, cellmate status, prison procedures, and the events surrounding his death. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychological intake and suicide risk assessment reports for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, conducted on July 8-10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It details his mental health evaluation, assessment of risk for sexual abusiveness (rated low), and suicide risk assessment (rated low), noting his high-profile case, sex trafficking charges, and upcoming bail hearing. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service records for Jeffrey Epstein from July 9-24, 2019, while he was incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It details initial suicide risk assessments, daily clinical contacts, and a significant event on July 23 where Epstein was found with a string around his neck, leading to a suicide watch and a subsequent risk assessment that concluded with a moderate acute suicide risk. This document is a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology reports from July 24-28, 2019, detailing Jeffrey Epstein's mental status and conditions while on suicide watch and psychological observation at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The reports document his denial of suicidal ideation, his vague and inconsistent account of an incident that left marks on his neck, his complaints about conditions in the Special Housing Unit (SHU), and his desire to be moved to general population. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons clinical notes and reports from late July and early August 2019 concerning inmate Jeffrey Epstein. It details his mental health status, his placement on and removal from psychological observation, an assessment of his competency for a disciplinary hearing related to a neck injury, and a suicide risk assessment. The records show his complaints about prison conditions, his interactions with staff, and his legal activities. This document contains Bureau of Prisons clinical records from August 2019 regarding Jeffrey Epstein's mental health status while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. It includes a clinical intervention note from August 8, 2019, where Epstein denied suicidal ideation, and internal emails discussing his housing and suicide watch status in late July 2019. This document is an FBI 302 report summarizing an interview with a Bureau of Prisons Senior Officer Specialist regarding the morning of Jeffrey Epstein's death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) on August 10, 2019. It details prison procedures, head counts, and the response to the medical emergency, and includes supporting count sheets and phone logs. This document is a detailed telephone call log from a specific station (6317) on August 10, 2019. It records numerous outgoing calls, including attempts to connect to internal extensions and external numbers, showing patterns of communication activity. This document contains an FBI 302 interview with inmate Johnny Contreras regarding his observations of the morning Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). It also includes an email about evidence return and an interview with a BOP psychologist regarding Epstein's intake screening. The Contreras interview provides a detailed eyewitness account of the discovery of Epstein's body and the immediate response by guards and medical personnel. This document contains two Bureau of Prisons forms assessing Jeffrey Epstein's risk of sexual abusiveness and suicide risk on July 8, 2019. The sexual abusiveness assessment identifies him as low risk despite his history, while the administrative note flags him as high suicide risk due to his high-profile case and pending court proceedings. This document contains FBI 302 interview reports from the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in August 2019. It includes interviews with three BOP corrections officers and one inmate, detailing procedures, events surrounding Epstein's prior suicide attempt in July 2019, and the morning he was found unresponsive. The document also includes related forms and an investigative report cover sheet. This document is a Bureau of Prisons investigation summary regarding an incident on July 23, 2019, where inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with a homemade noose around his neck. It details the initial response, medical findings, and subsequent interviews with Epstein and his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, concluding there was insufficient evidence of an assault and no need for separation. This document is a Bureau of Prisons Form 583 Report of Incident and related staff memoranda detailing the events of July 23, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center New York, where inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found with an orange cloth around his neck. The reports describe the response, Epstein's allegations that his cellmate Nicholas Tartaglione tried to kill and extort him, and the subsequent medical assessment. This document contains Bureau of Prisons records from the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York related to Jeffrey Epstein's incident of self-harm on July 23, 2019, and subsequent medical and psychological evaluations. It includes an injury assessment, incident report, administrative detention order, and psychology notes detailing Epstein's condition and statements after being found with a rope around his neck. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service clinical notes and reports from late July and early August 2019 concerning inmate Jeffrey Epstein. It details his mental status, complaints about conditions, an incident of self-mutilation, and competency evaluations while he was held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC-NY). This document contains Bureau of Prisons records from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, including a psychological services clinical contact note for Jeffrey Epstein dated August 8, 2019, and numerous 30-minute check sheets for the Special Housing Unit (SHU) for August 8-10, 2019. The records were provided to the FBI as part of a death investigation. This document is a collection of FBI 302 forms and Bureau of Prisons (BOP) administrative records from August 10, 2019, related to the death investigation of Jeffrey Epstein. It includes staff rosters for the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) for August 9-10, 2019, emergency contact information for MCC staff, and Sentry system records detailing Epstein's housing assignments and movements within the MCC from July 6 to August 10, 2019. This document contains Bureau of Prisons (BOP) administrative records and psychology service notes for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July to August 2019, detailing his custody assignments, mental health observations, and the incident leading to his placement on suicide watch on July 23, 2019. It includes an FBI form summarizing the provision of psychology notes to the FBI on September 6, 2019. This document is a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology reports detailing Jeffrey Epstein's mental status and suicide risk assessment following an incident on July 23, 2019, where he was found with a string around his neck in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). The reports cover his placement on and subsequent removal from Suicide Watch, his psychological observations, his claims of no memory of the incident, and his complaints about prison conditions. This document contains a Bureau of Prisons Suicide Risk Assessment and related psychological evaluation for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, conducted on July 9, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It details his mental state, denial of suicidality, risk factors, and protective factors, concluding his acute suicide risk was low. The document was later amended and an FBI form references the notes as part of a death investigation. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychological intake screenings, suicide risk assessments, and medical records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 8-9, 2019, and a hospital transfer form dated August 10, 2019. The records show Epstein was assessed as having no mental health diagnosis, low suicide risk, and low risk of sexual abusiveness while incarcerated at MCC New York. This document is a compilation of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) medical records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering the period from July 7, 2019, to August 10, 2019. It includes vital signs, medication orders, clinical encounter notes, health assessments, and a final FBI synopsis noting the provision of these medical notes for a death investigation. The records detail Epstein's medical conditions, treatments, and interactions with healthcare staff while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. This document is a compilation of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) medical records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering his intake screening, immunizations, vital signs, medical history, dental exams, and lab results from July to August 2019. It details his health status, prescribed medications, and medical restrictions while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. This document is a collection of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) medical records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 2019, detailing his health status, treatment refusals, and an injury incident. It includes notes on a neck injury he sustained in his cell on July 23, 2019, where he was found with a rope around his neck, and his subsequent placement on suicide watch. The records also show his refusal of an eye evaluation and document various medical complaints and chronic conditions.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the death investigation. The document records his housing assignments and movements within the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) from his admission on July 6, 2019, until August 10, 2019.

persons.name: Leonardo Fernandez
persons.context: Inmate housed near Epstein in the SHU. Interviewed about his observations of Epstein's routine and his own movements on August 9, 2019. He had no information on Epstein's death.

persons.name: Tyrelyshanti Criag
persons.context: Girlfriend of inmate Leonardo Fernandez who visited him at MCC on August 9, 2019, leading to Fernandez being placed in a dry room.

persons.name: Efrain Reyes
persons.context: Jeffrey Epstein's cellmate in SHU Cell 220 until August 9, 2019. Interviewed pursuant to a proffer agreement about his time as Epstein's bunkie.

persons.name: Michael Thomas
persons.context: A Bureau of Prisons Corrections Officer mentioned in interviews. His property (an iPhone) was returned to his defense counsel. He was on scene at the hospital after Epstein's death.

persons.name: Shannon Farrar
persons.context: Associate at the Law Offices of Montell Figgins, defense counsel for Corrections Officer Michael Thomas. Received returned property from the FBI.

persons.name: Montell Figgins
persons.context: Attorney whose law firm represents Corrections Officer Michael Thomas. Listed as the business address for property return.

persons.name: Carpenter
persons.context: Office of the Inspector General Special Agent who provided OIG forms from voluntary interviews of MCC employees.

persons.name: Wheeler
persons.context: FBI SA who requested the Evidence Control Unit change the status of returned evidence item 1844.

persons.name: Tartaglione
persons.context: Inmate who was briefly Jeffrey Epstein's cellmate in the SHU. An incident occurred between them on July 23, 2019, where Epstein was found with a loose noose.

persons.name: Robert
persons.context: Psychologist (likely Dr. Robert) consulted by Dr. [Redacted] regarding Epstein's risk factors during the initial intake.

persons.name: Noel
persons.context: A newer corrections officer mentioned as being on scene at the hospital after Epstein's death and known to have knowledge of suicide watch bunkie policy.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of all BOP records; inmate at the New York Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) facing charges of sex trafficking conspiracy and sex trafficking of minors. Document details his custody status, psychological observations, and requests/complaints while incarcerated.

persons.name: Schlessinger, K.
persons.context: Psychology staff member who completed the initial intake assessment on July 8, 2019, determining Epstein met criteria for Mental Health Care Code 1.

persons.name: Robert Nagle
persons.context: Consulted by the assessing psychologist regarding inmate Epstein's risk factors for suicidality due to his high-profile case and legal situation.

persons.name: Epstein's brother
persons.context: Mentioned by Epstein as his only family, though he states he does not have a close relationship with him.

persons.name: Epstein's attorney
persons.context: Epstein expresses confidence in him, describes him as competent, and requests a phone call to meet with him.

persons.name: Dr. [Redacted]
persons.context: The primary psychologist conducting suicide risk assessments, clinical interventions, and authoring the majority of the notes. Referred to as PhD/Chief Psychologist and On-Call Psychologist.

persons.name: Operations Lt.
persons.context: Notified the on-call psychologist in the early morning of July 23, 2019, that Epstein was being placed on suicide watch after being found with a string around his neck.

persons.name: Captain
persons.context: Was notified by the assessing psychologist about Epstein's statement (from the log) that his cellmate tried to kill him. The Captain stated they were already aware.

persons.name: h.D.
persons.context: The psychology provider who authored several of the clinical intervention reports, interviewed Epstein, and made housing recommendations.

persons.name: Nick
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate in the SHU. Epstein describes him as 'agitated' and reports the cellmate called him a 'pedophile' and was reading a newspaper article about him. Epstein asks to speak to him to understand what happened.

persons.name: syD
persons.context: A psychology provider who authored and amended clinical intervention reports on July 27-28, 2019.

persons.name: PsyD
persons.context: A psychology staff member (Doctor of Psychology) who conducted multiple clinical contacts, suicide risk assessments, and a competency evaluation for Epstein. The provider's name is redacted but the credential is shown.

persons.name: D/Chief Psychologist
persons.context: A chief psychologist who sees Epstein on July 29, 2019, provides supportive interventions, and decides on his return to the SHU.

persons.name: Unit Manager Proto
persons.context: Referred Jeffrey Epstein for a competency evaluation related to a disciplinary process for an incident report.

persons.name: Dr.
persons.context: A doctor referenced in prior suicide risk assessments from July 9, 2019, who documented Epstein's denial of mental health history and suicidal ideation.

persons.name: Nurse
persons.context: Medical staff member notified by the psychologist about Epstein's complaints of numbness in his arm and neck.

persons.name: Lt.
persons.context: A prison lieutenant involved in moving Epstein to a different cell due to a disruptive toilet and later informed about his need for an appropriate cellmate.

persons.name: Elissa
persons.context: Chief Psychologist at the Metropolitan Correctional Center who was involved in discussions about Epstein's housing and suicide watch status.

persons.name: Christopher Bush
persons.context: Credited in the document for developing the Suicide Risk Assessment Guide Version 3 used in the Bureau of Prisons.

persons.name: Scott Forbes
persons.context: Credited in the document for developing the Suicide Risk Assessment Guide Version 3 used in the Bureau of Prisons.

persons.name: S. Andrea
persons.context: Wrote the memorandum detailing the response to the body alarm and medical emergency for inmate Epstein on August 10, 2019.

persons.name: S. Jean
persons.context: The recipient of the memorandum from S. Andrea regarding the Epstein medical emergency.

persons.name: Thomas
persons.context: Worked in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) on the day of the incident. The interviewee reached out to him afterward.

persons.name: Nowell
persons.context: A fairly new Correctional Officer who worked in the SHU on the day of the incident. The interviewee 'popped' a door for him so he could use the bathroom.

persons.name: Johnny Contreras
persons.context: Inmate housed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at MCC who witnessed the discovery of Jeffrey Epstein's body in the adjacent cell on the morning of August 10, 2019. He provided a detailed account to the FBI and OIG.

persons.name: Andy Patel
persons.context: One of Johnny Contreras's attorneys present during his FBI/OIG interview on September 3, 2019.

persons.name: Jill Shellow
persons.context: One of Johnny Contreras's attorneys present during his FBI/OIG interview on September 3, 2019.

persons.name: Donald Yanella
persons.context: One of Johnny Contreras's attorneys present during his FBI/OIG interview on September 3, 2019.

persons.name: Frederico Rancier-Medrano
persons.context: An inmate housed in the MCC SHU from July 16-26, 2019. He provided a detailed account of Epstein's prior suicide attempt in July, including officer response and procedures.

persons.name: Ernest Hammer
persons.context: Attorney for Frederico Rancier-Medrano during his interview with investigators.

persons.name: Natali Todd
persons.context: Attorney for a BOP Senior Officer Specialist (SOS) during her interview with investigators.

persons.name: Lamine N'Diaye
persons.context: Warden of the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) who approved an inmate investigative report dated August 2, 2019.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate at the time of the incident. Interviewed by staff, stated he was asleep and discovered Epstein, and reported prior uncomfortable conversations with him.

persons.name: Hacinta Garcia
persons.context: Cellmate of Frederico Rancier-Medrano during his time in the MCC SHU in July 2019.

persons.name: Yoon Kang
persons.context: Conducted a medical assessment on inmate Nicholas Tartaglione on July 31, 2019, and found no injuries.

persons.name: Clarke
persons.context: A correctional officer who spoke with Epstein after the incident and relayed Epstein's allegations about Tartaglione to the lieutenant.

persons.name: Thomas, Michael
persons.context: Listed on the daily assignment roster as assigned to Suicide Watch and other posts. Mentioned in the incident report's 'Others Involved' section.

persons.name: Y. Joaquin
persons.context: Medical staff who examined and treated Jeffrey Epstein for injuries (erythema on neck and knee) after the incident.

persons.name: Viers, J
persons.context: Listed on the daily assignment roster for a control post.

persons.name: Nicholas John Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate in the Special Housing Unit at the time of the incident. He was present when Epstein was found and was later evaluated medically, stating he had no idea what happened and no injury.

persons.name: Thomas, M
persons.context: BOP staff member listed on an overtime log sheet from July 23, 2019.

persons.name: MLP
persons.context: Medical provider who conducted a physical examination of Epstein on July 9, 2019, noting constipation and prescribing medication.

persons.name: ALP
persons.context: Healthcare provider listed on Epstein's clinical encounter form.

persons.name: Lieutenant
persons.context: Unnamed lieutenant who photographed the incident scene, ordered administrative detention, and was involved in the incident response.

persons.name: PA -C
persons.context: Healthcare provider who evaluated Nicholas Tartaglione on July 31, 2019, in the Special Housing Unit.

persons.name: Doctor
persons.context: A Bureau of Prisons Special Investigative Services Lieutenant who provided the medical notes regarding Jeffrey Epstein to the FBI on August 10, 2019, as per the FBI synopsis.

persons.name: SSA
persons.context: The FBI Supervisory Special Agent who approved the FBI form documenting the receipt of the psychology notes.

persons.name: PhD/Chief Psychologist
persons.context: The chief psychologist who saw Epstein on July 29, 2019, and was consulted on July 30, 2019, regarding discontinuing psychological observation.

persons.name: PsyD/DAPC
persons.context: A psychology provider (possibly a Drug Abuse Program Coordinator) who conducted a follow-up appointment with Epstein on July 31, 2019.

persons.name: SHU Lt.
persons.context: The lieutenant in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) who was informed about Epstein's need for an appropriate cellmate.

persons.name: Cass
persons.context: The FBI agent who drafted the 302 forms documenting the receipt of information from BOP SIS Lt. Doctor.

persons.name: Reyes
persons.context: Listed as a security officer on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 9, 2019.

persons.name: Legrand
persons.context: Listed in the tool room assignment on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 9, 2019.

persons.name: Rickenbadrer
persons.context: Listed as an officer on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 9, 2019.

persons.context: Listed as an officer in multiple posts (OT, REAR GATE) on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 9, 2019.

persons.context: Listed as an officer on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 9, 2019.

persons.context: Listed as an officer in multiple posts (OT, DRY CELL) on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 9, 2019.

persons.context: Listed as an officer on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 9, 2019.

persons.context: Listed as an officer on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 9, 2019.

persons.context: Listed as an officer on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 9, 2019.

persons.context: Listed as an officer on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 9, 2019.

persons.name: Adams
persons.context: Listed as an officer in multiple posts (VISIT 01, ESCORT #2) on the MCC daily assignment rosters for August 9-10, 2019.

persons.name: Torres
persons.context: Listed as an officer for VISIT 02 on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 9, 2019.

persons.name: Solomon
persons.context: Listed as an officer for VISIT #3 on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 9, 2019.

persons.name: Melia
persons.context: Listed as an officer for the PHONE RM on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 9, 2019.

persons.context: Listed as an officer in multiple posts (EPO OFFICE, TREATY LT) on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 9, 2019.

persons.context: Listed as an officer for LOBBY #2 on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 9, 2019.

persons.context: Listed as an escort officer on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 9, 2019.

persons.context: Listed as a TNWDVR officer on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 9, 2019.

persons.context: Listed as an escort officer on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 9, 2019.

persons.context: Listed as an officer for TREATY 1 on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 9, 2019.

persons.context: Listed as an officer for TREATY 2 on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 9, 2019.

persons.name: ChimmIng
persons.context: Listed as an officer for LOBBY #2 on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 10, 2019.

persons.context: Listed as an officer for DRY CELL on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 10, 2019.

persons.context: Listed as an officer on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 10, 2019.

persons.context: Listed as an escort officer on the MCC daily assignment roster for August 10, 2019.

persons.name: Thomas Michael A
persons.context: An MCC employee whose emergency contact information (Edain Cheek) and residence address (Plainfield, NJ) were queried as part of the investigation.

persons.name: Cheek Edain
persons.context: Listed as the emergency contact for MCC employee Thomas Michael A.

persons.context: An MCC employee whose address information (Bronx, NY) was queried as part of the investigation.

persons.context: An individual whose address and check information (Pearl, MS) was queried, likely in relation to staff background checks.

persons.context: An individual whose address and check information (Brooklyn, NY) was queried, likely in relation to staff background checks.

persons.context: An MCC employee whose information was queried in the employee locator system.

persons.name: N. Reid
persons.context: Listed as the Unit Manager for Epstein's housing unit at the New York MCC, with contact extension provided in assignment history reports.

persons.name: Mila
persons.context: Psychology staff member who conducted a clinical contact with Epstein on July 10, 2019, documenting his condition and requests.

persons.context: Psychologist referenced in the Suicide Risk Assessment report dated July 9, 2019, who conducted an earlier assessment of Epstein.

persons.context: BOP psychologist who conducted the initial psychological intake screening and risk of sexual abusiveness assessment on Epstein on July 8, 2019.

persons.name: Kang, Yoon
persons.context: A PA-C who performed a PPD test on Epstein's right forearm and documented 'No Known Allergies' on July 6, 2019.

persons.name: Beaudouin, Robert
persons.context: A physician who conducted a chronic care evaluation of Jeffrey Epstein on July 14, 2019, documenting his medical history and prescribing medication.

persons.name: Joaquin, Y.
persons.context: Listed as the provider for Epstein's encounter on July 9, 2019, documenting immunizations and observations.

persons.name: DeBruce, Juanita
persons.context: Documented a dental screening encounter on July 18, 2019, noting Epstein had missed several appointments.

persons.name: Dale
persons.context: Counseled Jeffrey Epstein on July 24, 2019, regarding his refusal of an eye doctor evaluation, as noted on the treatment refusal form.

persons.name: Columba
persons.context: A nurse who performed and documented clinical encounters with Jeffrey Epstein on July 28, 2019, regarding neuropathy symptoms.

connections.description: Reyes was Epstein's cellmate (bunkie) in SHU Cell 220 until August 9, 2019, as part of the requirement for inmates on suicide watch.
Tartaglione was Epstein's first cellmate in the SHU. An incident on July 23, 2019, involved a loose noose found on Epstein's neck, which Epstein blamed on Tartaglione.
Dr. [Redacted] was the Chief Psychologist at MCC who conducted multiple suicide risk assessments on Epstein and managed his psychological observation status.
Criag is Fernandez's girlfriend who visited him at MCC, which led to Fernandez being suspected of receiving contraband.
Farrar, of the Law Offices of Montell Figgins, is the defense counsel for Corrections Officer Michael Thomas, as evidenced by the return of his property.
Dr. [Redacted] consulted with Dr. Robert about Epstein's non-psychological risk factors (high-profile case, sex offenses) during the initial intake.
Epstein expresses confidence in his attorney, describes him as competent, and requests to contact him.
Epstein identifies his brother as his only family but states they do not have a close relationship.
Dr. Nagle was consulted by the assessing psychologist regarding Epstein's suicide risk factors.
Epstein is the inmate patient undergoing psychological evaluation and intervention by the chief psychologist.
The Operations Lieutenant was involved in the custodial decision to place Epstein on suicide watch after an incident.
Were housed together in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). Epstein described Nick as 'agitated' and claimed Nick called him a 'pedophile'.
Clinical psychologist assessing Epstein's mental status, suicide risk, and providing interventions during his time on suicide watch and psychological observation.
PsyD is the primary psychologist conducting clinical assessments, providing interventions, and monitoring Epstein's mental status while he is in custody.
The Chief Psychologist evaluated Epstein, provided brief supportive interventions, and made the decision about his housing transition from the hospital area back to the SHU.
Unit Manager Proto initiated the disciplinary process referral that led to Epstein's competency evaluation.
Elissa, as Chief Psychologist, was involved in clinical oversight and housing decisions regarding Epstein's incarceration.
Both were Correctional Officers working in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) on the day of Jeffrey Epstein's death.
S. Andrea, as the Correctional Systems Officer, documented the medical emergency response for inmate Epstein.
Contreras was an inmate in a cell adjacent to Epstein's in the MCC SHU and witnessed the events surrounding the discovery of Epstein's body.
Patel was one of Contreras's attorneys present during his FBI/OIG interview.
Shellow was one of Contreras's attorneys present during his FBI/OIG interview.
Yanella was one of Contreras's attorneys present during his FBI/OIG interview.
Were cellmates in the MCC Special Housing Unit (SHU) from July 16 to July 26, 2019.
Medrano witnessed Epstein's prior suicide attempt in July 2019 and heard other inmates and officers making comments about him.
Hammer was present as Medrano's attorney during his interview with investigators.
Todd was present as the attorney for an unnamed BOP Senior Officer Specialist during her interview.
Were housed together in the Special Housing Unit at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. The report investigates a potential altercation but finds insufficient evidence of assault.
Officer Clarke communicated with Epstein after the incident, receiving his allegations against Tartaglione.
MLP Y. Joaquin provided medical examination and treatment to Epstein for injuries sustained during the incident.
Were housed together in cell 124 of the Special Housing Unit at MCC New York when Epstein was found with a rope around his neck.
MLP conducted the medical evaluation of Epstein after the July 23 incident, documenting his injuries and statements.
PsyD provided psychological evaluation and intervention to Epstein on July 27, 2019, while he was on psych observation.
PA -C conducted a medical evaluation of Tartaglione on July 31, 2019, in the SHU, following the incident with Epstein.
The lieutenant ordered Epstein's administrative detention, oversaw the incident response, and authorized photo documentation of the scene.
Clinical relationship where the Chief Psychologist evaluated Epstein and made decisions about his housing and observation status.
Epstein spent about 12 hours per day in attorney conferences, indicating frequent contact with his legal team.
Epstein talked to an inmate companion about investments, as noted in a Psych Observation Log.
Doctor, as a BOP SIS Lieutenant, was involved in the custodial oversight and documentation of inmate Epstein's confinement in the SHU.
BOP SIS Lt. Doctor provided investigative materials (rosters, contacts, Sentry data) to FBI Agent Cass, who documented the receipt.
As a BOP SIS Lieutenant, Doctor was involved in the custodial oversight and investigation related to inmate Jeffrey Epstein.
FBI Agent Cass was drafting documents for the death investigation of Jeffrey Epstein.
Edain Cheek is listed as the emergency contact for MCC employee Thomas Michael A.
Epstein was under the custodial supervision of Unit Manager N. Reid at the New York MCC, as indicated in assignment records.
Psychology provider Mila conducted clinical observation sessions with Epstein, assessing his mental status and addressing his complaints.
Psychologist Dr. M conducted a prior suicide risk assessment of Epstein, which is referenced in the later assessment report.
Epstein and Nick were cellmates in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). Epstein reported interpersonal tension, stating Nick called him a 'pedophile' and was reading about him in the newspaper.
M, the Chief Psychologist, conducted a clinical interview and suicide risk assessment of inmate Jeffrey Epstein.
Doctor, a BOP SIS Lieutenant, was involved in the custodial chain regarding Epstein's psychological notes and provided them to the FBI.
Chief psychologist who assessed Epstein for suicide risk on July 9, 2019, and classified him as CARE1-MH.
Psychologist who conducted Epstein's initial psychological intake and risk of sexual abusiveness assessment on July 8, 2019.
Chief psychologist consulted with Dr. Robert Nagle of Central Office regarding Epstein's risk factors for suicidality.
Medical provider who examined Epstein, diagnosed constipation, and prescribed medication on July 9, 2019.
BOP SIS Lieutenant provided prison psychology and medical notes to the FBI, as documented in FBI import forms approved by the SSA.
Kang performed a PPD test and documented allergies for Epstein as part of his intake medical assessment.
Beaudouin was involved in prescribing medication (insulin) and providing patient education to Epstein regarding his diagnoses.
The BOP SIS Lt. provided Epstein's medical notes to the FBI as part of the death investigation.
Joaquin, Y. (MLP) was the medical provider conducting Epstein's intake health screening and immunization assessment on July 9, 2019.
Dental Assistant DeBruce, Juanita documented a missed dental screening appointment for Epstein on July 18, 2019.
Dale counseled Epstein regarding his refusal of medical treatment (eye evaluation).
RN Columba assessed and documented Epstein's medical condition and symptoms on July 28, 2019.
BOP SIS Lt. Doctor provided Epstein's medical notes to the FBI as part of a death investigation.

events.title: Epstein Found with Noose
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a loose noose around his neck. He was placed on Suicide Watch. He told staff his cellmate Tartaglione tried to kill him.

events.title: Epstein Left Without Cellmate
events.description: Efrain Reyes, Epstein's cellmate, was released or moved from SHU Cell 220, leaving Epstein without a required bunkie. This was the last day Fernandez saw Epstein in his cell.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive / Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell in the morning and later pronounced dead. Lieutenants and officers were notified and responded to the hospital.

events.title: Epstein Signs New Will
events.description: It is noted that Epstein signed a new will on this date. The psychologist stated that had she known, it would have been a red flag prompting psychological observation.

events.title: Evidence Collection and Property Return
events.description: FBI documents the collection of a hard drive as part of the death investigation and the return of an iPhone to the attorney of Corrections Officer Michael Thomas.

events.title: Epstein's Initial Psychological Intake
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein arrived at MCC and completed the Psychological Services Intake Questionnaire (PSIQ). He denied any mental health history but was placed on observation due to risk factors.

events.title: Epstein's Court Proceeding
events.description: Epstein attended a court proceeding which could have given him 'bad news regarding his legal situation,' prompting precautionary psychological observation upon his return to jail.

events.title: Psychological Intake Assessment
events.description: Initial psychological intake screening at MCC New York. Epstein denied mental health history and was assessed for risk of sexual abusiveness (rated low).

events.title: Precautionary Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein was placed on psychological observation status after returning from court due to multiple suicide risk factors, though he denied suicidality.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: A formal suicide risk assessment was conducted. Epstein was found to be at low acute risk and absent chronic risk, with protective factors outweighing risk factors.

events.title: Upcoming Bail Hearing
events.description: Epstein reported he was going to have a bail hearing on the Monday following the assessment (July 8 or 15, 2019) and believed he would be released.

events.title: Previous Incarceration in Palm Beach
events.description: Epstein reported he previously served time in Palm Beach County jail on sex offense charges (soliciting prostitution).

events.title: Initial Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Epstein underwent a precautionary suicide risk assessment after returning from a court proceeding. He was found to have no history of mental health issues, no current suicidality, and was classified as CARE1-MH.

events.title: Placement in SHU
events.description: Epstein was released from psychological observation and housed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) in administrative detention with a cellmate for safety and security concerns.

events.title: Found with String Around Neck
events.description: Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck in the early morning hours, leading to his placement on suicide watch. The origin of the string (self-inflicted or by another) was unclear.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment After Incident
events.description: A formal suicide risk assessment was conducted. Epstein denied memory of the event and current suicidal ideation. The assessment noted a circular line on his neck, a sore throat, and a statement (from a log) that his cellmate tried to kill him. Overall acute suicide risk was assessed as Moderate.

events.title: Suicide Watch Initiated
events.description: Epstein was placed on continuous suicide watch with inmate companions after the string incident, per the psychologist's recommendation.

events.title: Epstein placed on Suicide Watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed on suicide watch following an incident in his cell that resulted in marks (a significant scar/scab) around his neck. The nature of the incident was unclear.

events.title: Epstein stepped down to Psychological Observation
events.description: After assessment, Epstein was removed from Suicide Watch and stepped down to Psychological Observation status, where he would be continuously observed by inmate companions and seen daily by psychology staff.

events.title: Daily psychology clinical contacts
events.description: A series of daily clinical interventions and assessments were conducted with Epstein while he remained on Psychological Observation. He consistently denied suicidal ideation and gave vague accounts of the neck injury incident.

events.title: Neck Injury Incident in SHU
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck, leading to an incident report for tattooing/self-mutilation. He stated he did not remember how it happened.

events.title: Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein was placed on psychological observation. He was seen daily by psychology staff, complained about prison conditions (noise, toilet), and was assessed for suicide risk and mental status.

events.title: Competency Evaluation for Disciplinary Process
events.description: Epstein was evaluated for competency to proceed with a disciplinary hearing regarding the July 23 neck injury incident. He was found competent to proceed.

events.title: Return to SHU and Status Hearing
events.description: Epstein was removed from psychological observation and returned to the Special Housing Unit (SHU). He reported going to court for a status hearing and adjusting to life in SHU with a cellmate.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment Triggered by Marshals
events.description: After returning from court, US Marshals had Epstein sign a form noting 'suicidal tendencies,' prompting a new suicide risk assessment. He denied being suicidal, and his overall risk was assessed as low.

events.title: Clinical follow-up session with Epstein
events.description: Epstein was seen for a follow-up session in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). He reported feeling okay, eating meals, having fair sleep, and denied any mental health symptoms, suicidal ideation, intention, or plan.

events.title: Discussion about Epstein's housing
events.description: The National Suicide Prevention Coordinator contacted Elissa about housing Epstein with another sex offender. Elissa planned to discuss this with executive staff.

events.title: Epstein removed from Psych Observation
events.description: Epstein was taken off Psych Observation and needed to be housed with an appropriate cellmate. No suicide watch or psych observation was active at that time.

events.title: Medical Emergency and Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: At 6:33 AM, a body alarm was activated in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) for a medical emergency involving inmate Jeffrey Epstein. EMS was called, arrived at 6:43 AM, and transported Epstein to a local hospital via ambulance at 7:10 AM.

events.title: FBI/OIG Interview of BOP Officer
events.description: A Senior Officer Specialist from the Bureau of Prisons was interviewed by an AUSA, OIG SA, and FBI SA regarding procedures and events on August 10, 2019, at the MCC.

events.title: Prison Head Counts
events.description: Standard head counts were conducted in the MCC at 12:00 AM, 3:00 AM, and 5:00 AM. The SHU reported a count of '72' inmates.

events.title: Telephone Communication Activity
events.description: A series of telephone calls are logged from station 6317 to various internal extensions and external numbers throughout the day.

events.title: Discovery of Epstein unresponsive
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in the morning. A guard discovered him, attempted to revive him with chest compressions and mouth-to-mouth, and medical personnel responded. He was pronounced dead.

events.title: Interview of Johnny Contreras
events.description: FBI and OIG agents interviewed inmate Johnny Contreras at the Southern District of New York regarding his eyewitness account of the morning Epstein was found dead.

events.title: Epstein psychological intake screening
events.description: A Bureau of Prisons psychologist conducted an intake interview with Jeffrey Epstein at MCC. Epstein denied any mental health history, suicide history, or substance abuse history.

events.title: Meeting regarding Epstein's cellmate
events.description: A meeting was held regarding Jeffrey Epstein's housing. Epstein's attorney opposed him having a cellmate, but BOP staff explained that due to his SHU status and sex offender designation, he needed one.

events.title: Evidence returned to Michael Thomas
events.description: FBI returned evidence item 1844 to Michael Thomas via his lawyer, Shannon Farrar, with concurrence from an AUSA.

events.title: Epstein's psychological assessments in prison
events.description: Bureau of Prisons psychology staff conducted assessments of Jeffrey Epstein's risk of sexual abusiveness and suicide risk while he was incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York.

events.title: Epstein's court proceeding
events.description: Epstein had a court proceeding that could potentially give him bad news regarding his legal situation, which was noted as a risk factor for suicide in the administrative note.

events.title: Epstein's Prior Suicide Attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein attempted to hang himself in his cell in the MCC SHU around 1:20-1:30 AM. His cellmate alerted officers. Response took several minutes, and officers were observed not administering CPR. Epstein was taken to medical and later placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at MCC. A body alarm sounded at approximately 6:33 AM. Medical performed CPR, and he was transported to the hospital.

events.title: Epstein's Attorney Meetings
events.description: Epstein was seen in the attorney conference area at MCC with 3 or 4 attorneys (2 females, 1 male) around 9 AM.

events.title: Interview of Corrections Officer
events.description: An unnamed corrections officer was interviewed regarding his shift when Epstein was found unresponsive. He discussed count procedures and requested a lawyer when shown a picture of an unnamed individual.

events.title: Interview of Frederico Rancier-Medrano
events.description: Inmate Frederico Rancier-Medrano was interviewed and provided a detailed account of Epstein's July suicide attempt and conditions in the SHU.

events.title: Interview of BOP Senior Officer Specialist
events.description: An unnamed BOP Senior Officer Specialist/Lieutenant was interviewed about her duties, rounds, and observations of Epstein on August 9, 2019.

events.title: Interview of BOP Senior Officer Specialist
events.description: An unnamed BOP Senior Officer Specialist was interviewed about his role as Control #2 on the morning of August 10, 2019, and his response to the body alarm when Epstein was found.

events.title: Epstein Found with Noose in Cell
events.description: At approximately 1:27 a.m., correctional staff found inmate Jeffrey Epstein lying on his cell floor in a fetal position with a homemade noose around his neck. He was breathing heavily and responsive but non-compliant. He was restrained, medically examined, and placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein Interview
events.description: At approximately 9:10 a.m., Jeffrey Epstein was interviewed by SIS staff. He claimed extreme fatigue, lack of memory of the incident, and stated he had no issues with his cellmate Tartaglione, despite a prior verbal altercation.

events.title: Tartaglione Interview
events.description: At approximately 10:00 a.m., Nicholas Tartaglione was interviewed. He stated he was asleep, discovered Epstein, and called for help. He reported prior conversations where Epstein made him uncomfortable by stating 'fourteen (14) is legal in most states' and complaining about his attorneys.

events.title: Epstein Placed in Administrative Detention
events.description: An Administrative Detention Order was issued, placing Jeffrey Epstein in detention pending classification.

events.title: Reported Suicide Attempt / Incident Involving Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: At approximately 1:27 AM, a call for assistance was made in the SHU. Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with an orange homemade cloth/rope around his neck, lying on the floor. He was unresponsive but breathing. Staff removed the cloth, restrained him, and transported him to the HA-Unit for suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein Alleges Cellmate Attempted Murder and Extortion
events.description: After becoming responsive, Epstein told staff he believed his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, tried to kill him. He also alleged Tartaglione had been trying to extort money from him for a week, threatening to beat him up if he didn't pay, and claimed Tartaglione said staff wouldn't report a beating due to Epstein's charges.

events.title: Medical Examination of Epstein
events.description: Upon arrival of medical staff, Epstein was examined by MLP Y. Joaquin, who noted a circular line of erythema at the base of the neck with friction marks and a small erythema on his left knee.

events.title: Epstein Found with Rope Around Neck
events.description: At approximately 1:27 AM, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell (124) with an orange homemade rope around his neck, sitting on the floor. He was breathing but unresponsive. Staff removed the rope and he was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Medical Evaluation of Epstein
events.description: At 06:20, Epstein was evaluated by MLP for neck injuries. He claimed he did not know how the marks occurred, stating 'I do not know. Just went to drink a little water and wake up snorting.' He had a circular line of erythema on his neck.

events.title: Psychological Evaluation of Epstein
events.description: PsyD evaluated Epstein on psych observation. Epstein stated he could not remember what happened in SHU, reported severe sleep deprivation prior to the incident, and expressed anxiety about returning to SHU. He denied current suicidal ideation.

events.title: Medical Evaluation of Tartaglione
events.description: PA -C evaluated Nicholas Tartaglione in the SHU. Tartaglione stated he felt good, had no acute complaints, and said regarding the Epstein incident, 'I have no idea what was going on. I didn't do anything and I have no injury.'

events.title: BOP Provides Psychology Notes to FBI
events.description: BOP SIS Lt. Doctor provided BOP Psychology Services notes regarding Jeffrey Epstein to the FBI, as referenced in an FBI form dated September 6, 2019.

events.title: Epstein Found with String Around Neck
events.description: Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck, leading to an incident report for self-mutilation (Code 228). He stated he did not remember how it happened.

events.title: Psych Observation Discontinued
events.description: Psychological observation was discontinued for Epstein after consultation with the Chief Psychologist. He was to be returned to SHU.

events.title: Court Status Hearing
events.description: Epstein reported he was going to court for a status hearing on this date.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment After Marshal's Form
events.description: A suicide risk assessment was conducted after US Marshals had Epstein sign a form noting 'suicidal tendencies' upon his return from court. The assessment concluded his overall acute suicide risk was LOW.

events.title: Epstein SHU Psychological Evaluation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was seen for a follow-up psychological session in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). He reported feeling okay, eating meals, having 'fair' sleep, and denied any mental health symptoms, depression, anxiety, or suicidal ideation.

events.title: BOP Provides Monitoring Logs to FBI
events.description: BOP SIS Lieutenant Doctor provided the MCC 30-minute round check sheets for the SHU (for dates 8/8, 8/9, and 8/10) and TRU-SCOPE logs to the FBI as part of the death investigation into Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: FBI Receives MCC Staff Rosters and Data
events.description: BOP SIS Lt. Doctor provides the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) staff rosters for August 9 and 10, 2019, staff emergency contact information, and Sentry system documentation regarding Jeffrey Epstein to the FBI.

events.title: Epstein Admitted to MCC
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is admitted to the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) as an adult pre-sentencing inmate.

events.title: Epstein Court Appearance
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is taken from MCC to court for an appearance, returning the same day.

events.title: Epstein's MCC Housing Assignments
events.description: Sentry records detail Epstein's multiple cell assignments within the MCC, including moves between housing units and specific cells (e.g., 204-206LAD, 205-124LAD, 202-201LAD).

events.title: Epstein admitted to NY MCC
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was admitted to the New York Metropolitan Correctional Center as a pre-sentencing adult inmate.

events.title: Psychological observation contact
events.description: Epstein was seen for a psychological observation contact in the hospital area. He presented numerous complaints about conditions but denied suicidal ideation and was deemed psychologically stable.

events.title: Epstein placed on suicide watch
events.description: Epstein was placed on suicide watch after being found in his cell with a string loosely hanging around his neck in the early morning. A suicide risk assessment was conducted later that day.

events.title: Epstein transported to hospital
events.description: BOP records show an assignment for Epstein: "ESC TRP TO LOC HOSP W/RETN-USM" (Escort Trip to Local Hospital with Return to USMS) at 0747 hours.

events.title: FBI receives psychology notes
events.description: An FBI form documents that on September 6, 2019, BOP SIS Lt. Doctor provided MCC psychology notes regarding Jeffrey Epstein to the FBI as part of a death investigation.

events.title: Suicide Watch Initiated
events.description: A suicide watch was initiated for Jeffrey Epstein following the discovery of the string around his neck.

events.title: Removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein was removed from Suicide Watch and stepped down to Psychological Observation after 31 hours and 5 minutes. He was transferred to a medical center.

events.title: Daily Psychological Observations
events.description: Epstein was seen daily by psychology staff while on Suicide Watch and Psychological Observation. He consistently denied suicidal ideation, complained about SHU conditions, and maintained he had no memory of the neck incident.

events.title: Epstein returns from court, placed on observation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein returned from a court proceeding in the evening and was placed on precautionary psychological observation by BOP staff.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment conducted
events.description: A formal suicide risk assessment was conducted on Jeffrey Epstein by the Chief Psychologist. Epstein denied any suicidal ideation, was future-oriented, and was assessed as having a low acute suicide risk.

events.title: BOP provides psychology notes to FBI
events.description: BOP SIS Lt. Doctor provided the psychology notes from July 9, 2019, regarding Jeffrey Epstein to the FBI as part of a death investigation.

events.title: FBI documents receipt of notes
events.description: The FBI created a form documenting the receipt of the psychology notes regarding Jeffrey Epstein, titling it for a death investigation.

events.title: Psychological Intake Screening
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes initial psychological intake screening at MCC-NY. He denies any mental health history, current symptoms, or suicidality. He is assessed as low risk for sexual abusiveness and classified CARE1-MH.

events.title: Consultation on Suicide Risk
events.description: Chief psychologist M consults with Dr. Robert Nagle (Central Office) regarding Epstein's risk factors for suicidity. Staff are instructed to notify psychology immediately upon Epstein's return from court.

events.title: Medical Examination
events.description: Epstein undergoes a physical examination. He is diagnosed with constipation and prescribed Bisacodyl. He refuses genital and rectal exams. The encounter is later cosigned by an MD.

events.title: Hospital Transfer Form Prepared
events.description: A Bureau of Prisons 'Inmate Local Hospital' transfer form is generated for Jeffrey Epstein, listing his health problems, medications, allergies (fish), and pending appointments.

events.title: BOP Provides Notes to FBI
events.description: BOP SIS Lt. Doctor provides MCC psychology notes from July 8-9, 2019, and BOP medical notes regarding Jeffrey Epstein to the FBI.

events.title: FBI Documents Received Notes
events.description: FBI creates import forms (Serial 93 and 94) documenting receipt of psychology and medical notes regarding Jeffrey Epstein, linking them to the death investigation case.

events.title: Initial Medical Intake
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein's initial medical intake at the Bureau of Prisons, including a PPD test and allergy assessment.

events.title: Chronic Care Physician Evaluation
events.description: A detailed clinical encounter where Epstein was evaluated for multiple chronic conditions including hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, and back pain. Medications were prescribed.

events.title: Medical Notes Provided to FBI
events.description: BOP SIS Lt. Doctor provided Jeffrey Epstein's medical notes to the FBI for the death investigation, as documented in an FBI synopsis.

events.title: Epstein Intake Medical Screening
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein underwent a comprehensive medical intake screening at MCC New York, including vital signs, physical exam, immunization history, and lab work.

events.title: Epstein Dental Health Assessment
events.description: Epstein received a dental health history screening and exam, revealing conditions like sleep apnea, hypertriglyceridemia, and gingival recession.

events.title: BOP Provides Medical Notes to FBI
events.description: As noted in an FBI form, on August 10, 2019, a BOP SIS Lieutenant provided medical notes regarding Jeffrey Epstein to the FBI as part of a death investigation.

events.title: Epstein Found with Neck Injury in Cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell (Special Housing Unit Z05 - Cell 124) with a rope around his neck, sitting on the floor. He had a circular line of erythema (redness) at the base of his neck. He was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein Refuses Eye Evaluation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signed a Bureau of Prisons Medical Treatment Refusal form, refusing a recommended eye doctor evaluation.

events.title: Epstein Chronic Care Evaluation
events.description: Dr. Robert Beaudouin conducted a chronic care physician evaluation of Jeffrey Epstein, documenting his medical history including hypertriglyceridemia, sleep apnea, and spinal stenosis.

events.title: Epstein Reports Neuropathy Symptoms
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein reported to medical staff that he woke up with a lack of control and 'pins and needles' in his right arm, which was assessed as neuropathy.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was housed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at MCC, specifically in Cell 220 on L Tier, and was required to have a cellmate (bunkie) due to being on suicide watch/observation.
Efrain Reyes was Epstein's cellmate until August 9, 2019. After Reyes left, Epstein was left without a cellmate, violating the protocol for inmates with his risk profile.
The Chief Psychologist conducted three suicide risk assessments on Epstein, an unusual number. She noted that the lack of a cellmate and understaffing contributed to his death.

Multiple Bureau of Prisons staff (lieutenants, corrections officers) were interviewed about prison procedures, rounds, counts, and their knowledge of Epstein's need for a cellmate, revealing potential procedural failures.
Epstein signed a new will on August 8, 2019, a fact the psychologist stated would have been a significant red flag had she been aware, potentially leading to different monitoring.
On July 8-10, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was assessed by Bureau of Prisons psychology staff at MCC New York and found to be at low risk for sexual abusiveness and low acute risk for suicide.
Epstein denied any history of mental health treatment, suicidal ideation, or being a victim/perpetrator of abuse, and was classified as requiring no regular mental health intervention (Care Level 1).

The assessments were triggered by his high-profile case, sex trafficking charges, pre-trial status, and a court proceeding that might have delivered bad news, leading to precautionary psychological observation.

Epstein expressed a future orientation, confidence in his attorney, a belief he would be released at an upcoming bail hearing, and identified protective factors like his business and community support.
The document records consultation with BOP Central Office psychologist Dr. Robert Nagle regarding Epstein's suicide risk due to the high-profile nature of his case.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck, leading to his placement on suicide watch.

A subsequent suicide risk assessment that day noted Epstein denied memory of the event and current suicidal ideation, but also referenced a log entry where Epstein allegedly told staff his 'cellmate tried to kill him.'
The psychologist's assessment concluded Epstein's overall acute suicide risk was 'Moderate' and he was to remain on suicide watch for observation.
Throughout the documented period (July 9-24, 2019), Epstein consistently denied any history of mental health treatment, substance abuse, and past or present suicidal ideation in clinical interviews.
Epstein's incarceration was characterized by numerous complaints about conditions (uniform, property, phone calls, diet) and a focus on his upcoming bail hearing and legal case.
Jeffrey Epstein was placed on suicide watch on July 23, 2019, after an incident that left a significant scar/scab around his neck. He claimed to have no memory of how it happened.
Epstein consistently and adamantly denied current or past suicidal ideation, intent, or plans throughout the assessment period, stating he was invested in his legal case and had a 'wonderful life'.
Epstein expressed fear for his safety if returned to the SHU with his previous cellmate, citing the cellmate's agitation and the presence of MS-13 gang members on the unit.

Psychology staff noted Epstein's account of the neck injury was vague and inconsistent, and he did not exhibit symptoms of cognitive or dissociative disorders that would explain the claimed memory lapse.
The reports document Epstein's complaints about conditions in the SHU, including noise, smell, restrictions, and difficulties working on his legal case and sleeping.
Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell on July 23, 2019, with a string loosely tied around his neck, an incident he claimed not to remember.

Clinical notes from late July 2019 detail Epstein's complaints about prison conditions, including disruptive toilet noise, inability to sleep even with a CPAP machine, and numbness in his arm and neck.
A competency evaluation on July 30, 2019, found Epstein competent to proceed with a disciplinary process related to the neck injury incident.

On August 1, 2019, US Marshals had Epstein sign a form labeling him with 'suicidal tendencies,' leading to a suicide risk assessment that concluded his risk was low and protective factors (future plans, social support, religious beliefs) overrode risk factors.
Epstein was frequently in attorney conferences and attended legal visits and court hearings during this period, indicating active legal proceedings.
On August 8, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein denied any suicidal ideation, intention, or plan during a clinical follow-up session in the SHU.
Epstein reported spending his days and evenings with his attorneys in the attorney conference room while incarcerated.
Internal emails from late July 2019 show discussions about Epstein's housing, including consideration of placing him with another sex offender.
Epstein was taken off Psych Observation on July 30, 2019, and needed appropriate cellmate housing at that time.
The document includes detailed Bureau of Prisons suicide risk assessment protocols and guidelines used for inmate evaluations.
The document records the official timeline of the response to Jeffrey Epstein's medical emergency on August 10, 2019, starting with a body alarm at 6:33 AM.
A BOP officer was interviewed and stated that video coverage of the SHU range was not operational during her shift on the morning of Epstein's death.
Prison count procedures are detailed, showing head counts were supposed to be verified and documented, with the SHU reporting 72 inmates.
Supporting documents include official count sheets for August 10, 2019, and telephone call logs from around the time of the incident.
The interviewee stated she 'popped' a door for Officer Nowell so he could use a bathroom, indicating movement in the area prior to the emergency.
The document is a raw telephone call log, showing technical details of calls from station 6317.
The log records numerous call attempts and connections on August 10, 2019, including calls to internal extensions (e.g., 6468, 6450, 6313, 6314) and external numbers (e.g., 16464230779, 12019560693).
The data includes timestamps, call types (e.g., LINE TO LINE, LINE TO TRUNK, ONE LINE), call statuses (e.g., DIALING, ANSWER, IN CONVERSATION, BUSY), and routing information.
No named individuals, locations, or specific events related to the Epstein case are mentioned in this technical log excerpt.
Inmate Johnny Contreras provided a detailed eyewitness account of guards discovering Jeffrey Epstein's body, attempting CPR, and the subsequent response by medical personnel.
Contreras stated Epstein appeared dead when he was first seen, had no visible marks on his neck, and was later seen with a sheet that had a loop and knot.
Contreras reported that after the incident, MCC personnel covered cell windows and brought in dividers to block views and cameras.

Epstein's psychological intake screening on July 8, 2019, noted he denied any mental health history, suicidal ideation, or substance abuse, and was assessed as requiring no regular mental health intervention.
On August 9, 2019, Epstein's attorney argued against him having a cellmate, but BOP staff insisted it was required due to his SHU status and sex offender designation.

On July 8, 2019, the Bureau of Prisons assessed Jeffrey Epstein as 'Low Risk of Abusiveness' for sexual behavior in prison despite noting his history of prior sexual abuse perpetration in the community.
The same day, prison psychology staff flagged Epstein as high risk for suicide due to his high-profile case, sex offense charges, pre-trial status, and pending court proceedings.
Epstein declined sex offender treatment programming recommendations made by prison psychology staff.
Prison staff were instructed to place Epstein on suicide watch if he returned from court after duty hours and to notify the on-call psychologist immediately.
The document reveals the Bureau of Prisons was aware of Epstein's suicide risk factors but assessed him as low risk for sexual abusiveness in the institutional setting.

An inmate witness, Frederico Rancier-Medrano, provided a detailed account of Jeffrey Epstein's prior suicide attempt in July 2019, describing a delayed officer response, lack of CPR, and officers making fun of Epstein.

Multiple BOP corrections officers were interviewed, revealing procedural concerns such as counts not being conducted properly, officers working alone in high-security units, and counts being done 'when they wanted to'.

One corrections officer, when shown a picture of an unnamed individual during his interview, immediately requested a lawyer and stated, 'I want to be clear, I never brought stuff into the jail or allowed stuff in. I never did that.'
Epstein's cellmate at the time of his July suicide attempt was reportedly a former police officer.
Investigators seized a corrections officer's cell phone pursuant to a search warrant but he refused to provide the passcode.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his prison cell with a homemade noose around his neck, resulting in visible neck injuries (erythema and friction marks).
Epstein told investigators he had not slept in approximately twenty days and had no memory of the incident, claiming he simply woke up on the floor.

Cellmate Nicholas Tartaglione reported a prior conversation where Epstein stated, 'fourteen (14) is legal in most states and I don't understand what's the problem here,' which made Tartaglione uncomfortable.
The investigation concluded there was insufficient evidence that Epstein was assaulted by Tartaglione and recommended no separation between the inmates was warranted.
Epstein was issued an incident report for 'code 228 - Self Mutilation' following the event and was placed on suicide watch.
On July 23, 2019, at ~1:27 AM, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with an orange homemade cloth/rope around his neck, in an apparent suicide attempt.
Epstein later alleged his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, tried to kill him and had been attempting to extort money from him for a week, threatening violence.
Tartaglione's account was that he was asleep, felt something hit his legs, turned on the light, and saw Epstein with a string around his neck before calling guards.
Medical examination revealed a circular red mark (erythema) on Epstein's neck with friction marks and a minor mark on his knee.
The document includes multiple staff memoranda and a Form 583 incident report, indicating a formal Bureau of Prisons review of the event.
Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell at approximately 1:27 AM on July 23, 2019, with an orange homemade rope around his neck, in what was documented as a 'Possible Suicide Attempt.'
Epstein told medical staff he did not know how the neck injuries occurred, stating, 'I do not know. Just went to drink a little water and wake up snorting.'
Epstein's cellmate at the time was Nicholas Tartaglione, who later stated to medical staff he had 'no idea what was going on' and denied any involvement or injury.

Psychological notes from July 27, 2019, indicate Epstein reported sleeping only about 30 minutes per night for the five nights prior to the incident due to noise in SHU and could not remember the event that caused the neck marks.
An FBI form dated September 6, 2019, notes that on August 10, 2019, BOP SIS Lt. Doctor provided BOP Psychology Services notes regarding Jeffrey Epstein to the FBI as part of a death investigation.
On July 23, 2019, Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck. He claimed no memory of the event, and it was unclear if he did it himself or if someone else did.
Epstein was evaluated and found COMPETENT to proceed with the disciplinary process related to the July 23 self-mutilation incident.
Epstein frequently complained about noise in the SHU, comparing it to a distressing experience, and mentioned a possible aversion to noise akin to traits on the autism spectrum.

A suicide risk assessment on August 1, 2019, was triggered because US Marshals had Epstein sign a form labeling him with 'suicidal tendencies.' The assessment concluded his risk was low, citing protective factors like future plans, religious beliefs, and support from friends and lawyers.
Clinical notes reveal Epstein spent extensive time (about 12 hours per day) in attorney conferences, indicating active legal preparation during this period.
On August 8, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was housed in the SHU, had a cellmate, and spent his days and evenings with his attorneys in the conference room.
Epstein denied any suicidal ideation, intention, or plan during his psychological evaluation on August 8, 2019.
The Bureau of Prisons maintained detailed 30-minute check sheets for the SHU, documenting irregular visual checks of inmates at least twice per hour.
These prison records (check sheets and a TRU-SCOPE log) were provided to the FBI by a BOP SIS Lieutenant on August 10, 2019, for a death investigation.
The psychological contact note indicates Epstein was on a routine schedule for weekly rounds and monthly SHU reviews.
The FBI formally requested and received detailed staff rosters for the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) for August 9 and 10, 2019, as part of the death investigation of Jeffrey Epstein.
Sentry system records show Jeffrey Epstein was moved between multiple cells within the MCC from July 6, 2019 (his admission) until August 10, 2019.
The document includes emergency contact and address information for several MCC staff members, indicating the investigation involved background checks on personnel.
The records show Epstein was housed in a cell designated '204-206LAD' from July 29, 2019, until the record's end on August 10, 2019.
The FBI 302 forms are dated September 6, 2019, documenting evidence collected on August 10, 2019, shortly after Epstein's death.
Jeffrey Epstein was in custody at the New York MCC from at least July 6, 2019, charged with sex trafficking conspiracy and sex trafficking of minors.

On July 23, 2019, Epstein was placed on suicide watch after being found in his cell with a string loosely around his neck; the suicide risk assessment notes he later told staff his cellmate tried to kill him, a claim he did not repeat to the assessing psychologist.

BOP psychology notes from July 2019 repeatedly state Epstein denied any suicidal ideation, intention, or plan and appeared psychologically stable, though he voiced numerous complaints about jail conditions.
An FBI form dated September 6, 2019, indicates BOP psychology notes regarding Epstein were provided to the FBI for a death investigation, following Epstein's death in August 2019.
Epstein's BOP records list his security threat as "HISTORY OF COMMITTING RAPE" and note he was on a psychological observation status and mental health care level.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck and a circular mark on his neck, but he claimed to have no memory of how it happened.
Epstein was placed on Suicide Watch but consistently and adamantly denied any suicidal ideation, intent, or history of self-harm throughout multiple psychological assessments.
Epstein expressed fear for his safety in the SHU, citing his cellmate's agitation and the presence of MS-13 gang members, and requested housing in general population or a 'safer' unit.

Psychological staff noted the incident's cause remained unclear due to Epstein's vague and inconsistent accounts and his claimed memory lapse, despite him showing no signs of cognitive or dissociative disorders.

The reports document Epstein's high-profile status, recent bail denial, and lack of strong family connections as static risk factors, but his future orientation and commitment to his legal case were noted as protective factors.
On July 9, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was assessed by a BOP psychologist and found to have a low acute suicide risk and an absent chronic suicide risk.
Epstein explicitly denied any past or present suicidal ideation, intention, or plan during the assessment and was described as future-oriented, with plans for a bail hearing.

The assessment notes Epstein's risk factors included his high-profile case, sex offense charges, pre-trial status, and a recent court proceeding, but these were outweighed by numerous protective factors.
An FBI form dated September 6, 2019, documents that these psychology notes were provided by the BOP on August 10, 2019, as part of a 'DEATH INVESTIGATION' regarding Jeffrey Epstein.
Epstein reported his only family was a brother with whom he did not have a close relationship, and he denied any history of mental health treatment or substance abuse.

On July 8-9, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was assessed by BOP psychology as having no mental health diagnosis, no history of treatment, no current suicidal ideation, and was classified as 'CARE1-MH' (lowest care level).

Epstein was assessed as being at 'Low Risk of Abusiveness' for sexual behavior in prison, though he had risk factors including prior sexual abuse perpetration in the community and prior violent offense convictions.

A chief psychologist noted Epstein had various risk factors for suicidality including his high-profile case, sex offense charges, pre-trial status, and an upcoming court proceeding, prompting a precautionary watch status.

A medical examination on July 9, 2019, noted Epstein had constipation (prescribed medication) and refused genital and rectal exams. A transfer form dated August 10, 2019, lists multiple health issues including hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, and hypertension.

BOP psychology and medical notes from July 2019 were provided to the FBI by a BOP SIS Lieutenant on August 10, 2019, and formally documented by the FBI in September 2019 as part of the death investigation.
Jeffrey Epstein's BOP medical records cover July 7, 2019, to August 10, 2019, the period leading up to his death.
Epstein had multiple diagnosed health issues including hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, hypertension, prediabetes, and chronic low back pain with neuralgia.
He was prescribed medications including insulin (Lantus), a Medrol dose pack for pain, and treatments for constipation.
An FBI synopsis dated September 6, 2019, states that on August 10, 2019, a BOP SIS Lieutenant provided these medical notes regarding Epstein for a death investigation.
Epstein's personal CPAP machine (serial # P1131281381) was in BOP possession, having been taken when he was arrested.
Jeffrey Epstein's medical intake on July 9, 2019, showed no signs of recent trauma, needle marks, or wounds, and noted he was born in the USA.
Epstein had multiple diagnosed health conditions including hypertriglyceridemia, sleep apnea, constipation, low back pain, and neuralgia.
He was prescribed several medications including insulin, steroids (methylprednisolone), omega-3 capsules, and laxatives while in custody.
An FBI form dated September 6, 2019, indicates BOP medical notes were provided on August 10, 2019, for a 'death investigation' regarding Epstein.
Lab results from July 9, 2019, showed significantly high triglycerides (413 mg/dL) and cholesterol levels, and a negative HIV test.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with a rope around his neck and marks of erythema and abrasion on his neck, leading to his placement on suicide watch.
Epstein insinuated to a medical provider on July 24, 2019, that his neck injuries 'had to do with his room mate,' but refused to elaborate further.
Epstein refused a recommended eye doctor evaluation on July 24, 2019, signing an official BOP treatment refusal form.
BOP medical notes regarding Epstein were provided to the FBI on August 10, 2019, as part of a death investigation, per an FBI form synopsis.
Epstein's documented chronic medical conditions included hypertriglyceridemia, obstructive sleep apnea, L4-L5 spinal stenosis, and low back pain.
